text: language notes topic five meals and
mealtimes part two let's talk about a
meal that's very common and very popular
on the weekend especially on Sunday
brunch brunch as you can see is a
combination of breakfast and lunch a
brunch is a late morning meal maybe
around 11 o'clock perhaps even 12 it's a
meal that has both breakfast foods and
lunch foods let's also talk about snacks
snacks are the little foods that you eat
between meals at schools at day care
centers there are snack times a morning
snack time might be around 10:00 or
10:30 a.m. after school children come
home and they also have a snack an
afternoon snack I already talked about a
potluck dinner and I described what a
buffet is let me also mention some other
meals that you might be invited to in
warmer weather you might be invited to
have a picnic that's a meal eaten
outside at a picnic table or perhaps on
a blanket placed on the ground people
pack their picnic basket they pack foods
or perhaps buy foods and they carry it
to a picnic area and they share their
meal outdoors at a barbecue or cookout
people also eat outdoors the difference
is they first cook outdoors
they usually grill some kind of meat
barbecue is sometimes written as BB q
barbecues cookouts picnics those are all
informal events in contrast a banquet is
a large formal gathering special foods
are prepared often after that formal
meal an award of some kind is given to
one person or perhaps to a number of
people so a banquet is held on a very
special occasion
before I end let me talk very briefly
about etiquette etiquette refers to
rules for behavior how someone should
behave in a certain social situation we
can talk about table etiquette rules for
behavior at the dinner table these are
the kinds of rules that parents try to
teach their children for example I teach
my children that the napkin is unfolded
and is placed on their lap table
etiquette is commonly referred to as
table manners now for some these rules
are important for others they're not so
important but most parents in the u.s.
makes some kind of effort to teach their
kids these rules here's what you might
hear them say place your napkin on your
lap we also say no elbows on the table
don't talk with your mouth full wait
until everyone has been served before
eating
if you're serving yourself use the
serving spoons or Forks to place food on
your dish then of course you use your
own utensils to eat the food from your
dish if you're a guest
thank your host or hostess and pay them
a compliment but for young children
parents usually say don't forget to say
thank you let me share one more note
about etiquette some families choose to
say grace grace is a prayer said before
meals not every family or every person
has this practice if you're invited to
dinner and the family says grace the
polite thing to do is simply just remain
quiet allow them to finish their grace
and then start eating the meal together
if you sit down to an American table you
might get confused by all the different
utensils just remember the general rule
work from the outside in for example
we'd use a salad fork before a dinner
fork this picture shows a rather formal
play setting I've asked my children to
help me they're going to set the table
for an everyday dinner
do you know how to set the table
yes would you show me yes so this is the
placemat at first we put the plate in
the center then we have a napkin and we
put it on the left then we have a fork
which we put on the napkin okay then
that we put then we have a knife on the
right facing inward and then we have a
spoon where we put next to the knife and
what if there's a beverage and if
there's a beverage you have a glass and
you put it in front of the full of
guys I'm sure you all know the word
spoon but perhaps you don't know the
specific names of different kinds of
spoons for example soup spoon teaspoon
tablespoon
likewise there's a difference between a
dinner knife and a butter knife
that's all for this lesson about meals
and mealtimes
